description: How to register for Self Assessment if you need to send a tax return or want to make voluntary Class 2 National Insurance payments.

details.body:
Use this tool to find out how to register for Self Assessment.

You must register for Self Assessment by 5 October 2024 if you have to send a tax return and you have not sent one before.

This service is also available in Welsh (Cymraeg).

If you’ve registered before

If you’ve registered for Self Assessment before but did not send a tax return last year, you must register again.

If you’re waiting for a Unique Taxpayer Reference (UTR), you can check when you can expect a reply from HMRC.

Before you start

You should check if you need to send a tax return before registering.

nodes.body:
There are different ways to register if you’re self-employed, registering a partner or partnership, or you need to register for any other reason.

You can check what being self-employed means if you’re unsure.

options.label: You're self-employed (for example, a sole trader)
You're a partner in a business partnership
For another reason (for example, you have income from a pension or a property)

nodes.title: Why do you need to send a Self Assessment tax return?

nodes.body: The last tax year started on 6 April 2022 and ended on 5 April 2023.

options.label: No, I'm registering for the first time

nodes.title: Did you send a tax return last year?

nodes.body: The last tax year started on 6 April 2022 and ended on 5 April 2023.

options.label: No, but I have registered before
No, I'm registering for the first time

nodes.title: Did you send a tax return last year?

nodes.body:
You must tell HMRC by 5 October if you need to send a tax return and you have not sent one before.

What you’ll need to register

You’ll need your:

  • full name
  • postal address (this can be outside of the UK)
  • date of birth
  • daytime telephone number
  • UK National Insurance number, if you have one

You’ll be asked to explain why you’re registering for Self Assessment. Check if you need to send a tax return if you’re not sure.

Register online

Start now

You need a Government Gateway user ID and password to register. If you do not already have a user ID you can create one when you sign in for the first time.

If you cannot use the online service

  1. Fill in form SA1.
  2. Print and post it to HMRC, using the postal address shown on the form.

What happens next

You’ll usually get an activation code for your new account in the post within 7 working days (21 if you’re abroad). It may take longer during busy periods. 

If you have not received your activation code within 7 (or 21 days), you can check when to expect it.

When you get the code, sign in to activate your Self Assessment.

You can replace an activation code if you do not receive it or you lose it.

After you register

You’ll usually get your Unique Taxpayer Reference (UTR) by post in 15 working days (21 days if you’re abroad), but it may take longer during busy periods. You’ll get it sooner in your personal tax account or HMRC app.

You can find a UTR number if you’ve lost it.
nodes.title: Register for Self Assessment if you're not self-employed

nodes.body:
You’ll need to register for both:

  • Self Assessment
  • Class 2 National Insurance

To register, you’ll need to sign into your tax account and select ‘Add a tax to your account to get online access to a tax, duty or scheme’.

You’ll need a Government Gateway user ID and password to sign in. If you do not have a user ID, you’ll be able to create one.

When to register

You must tell HMRC by 5 October if you need to send a tax return and you have not sent one before. You could be fined if you do not.

If you cannot register online

You can use form CWF1 to register for Self Assessment and Class 2 National Insurance.

The address to send the form to is:

Self Assessment
HM Revenue and Customs
BX9 1AN
United Kingdom

You’ll need to have all your information ready as you cannot save a partly completed form.

What happens next

You’ll usually get your Unique Taxpayer Reference (UTR) by post in 15 working days (21 days if you’re abroad), but it may take longer during busy periods.

If you have not received your UTR within 15 (or 21 days), you can check when to expect it.

You’ll get it sooner in your HMRC app.

HMRC will contact you by email or post telling you to complete a Self Assessment tax return before it’s due.

You can find a UTR number if you’ve lost it.
nodes.title: Register for Self Assessment if you’re self-employed

nodes.body:
Register for Self Assessment using form SA401.

If you need to register your partnership

You must also register your partnership if you’re the ‘nominated partner’.

There are different ways to register:

  • for limited liability partnerships
  • if you’re a partner that’s not an individual, for example a company or a trust

What you’ll need

To register using the online form, you’ll need to sign in using your Government Gateway user ID and password.

You’ll also need your Unique Taxpayer Reference (UTR) number.

When to register

You must tell HMRC by 5 October if you need to complete a tax return and have not sent one before. You could be fined if you do not.
nodes.title: Register if you're a partner or partnership

nodes.body:
You must file your Self Assessment tax return online before the deadline of 31 January.

If you did not send your return online

Create a tax account and sign up for Self Assessment.

You’ll usually get an activation code for your new account in the post within 7 working days (21 if you’re abroad), but it may take longer during busy periods.. 

If you have not received your activation code within 7 (or 21 days), you can check when to expect it.

When you get the code, sign in to activate your Self Assessment.

You can replace an activation code if you do not receive it or you lose it.
nodes.title: You're already registered for Self Assessment

nodes.body:
You can sign in to reactivate your online account for Self Assessment.

You’ll need your Government Gateway user ID and password to sign in.

You’ll also need your Unique Taxpayer Reference (UTR) number.

If you cannot use the online form

You can use form CWF1 to reactivate your account.

You’ll need your Unique Taxpayer Reference (UTR) number.

The address to send the form to is:

Self Assessment
HM Revenue and Customs
BX9 1AN
United Kingdom
nodes.title: You need to reactivate your account

nodes.body:
You must file your Self Assessment tax return online before the deadline of 31 January.

If you became self employed after registering for Self Assessment, you still need to register for Self Assessment as a sole trader. This will register you for Class 2 National Insurance contributions and help you qualify for benefits like the State Pension.

If you cannot use the online form

You can use form CWF1 to register for Self Assessment as a sole trader.

You’ll need your Unique Taxpayer Reference (UTR) number.

The address to send the form to is:

Self Assessment
HM Revenue and Customs
BX9 1AN
United Kingdom

If you did not use the online service last year

Create your tax account and sign up for Self Assessment.

You’ll usually get an activation code for your new account in the post within 7 working days (21 if you’re abroad). 

If you have not received your activation code within 7 (or 21 days), you can check when to expect it.

When you get the code, sign in to activate your Self Assessment.

You can replace an activation code if you do not receive it or you lose it.
nodes.title: You're already registered for Self Assessment

nodes.body:
Sign in to your tax account to reactivate your Self Assessment.

You’ll need your Government Gateway user ID and password.

You’ll also need your Unique Taxpayer Reference (UTR) number.
nodes.title: You need to reactivate your account
